narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this class is the first to teach me how to think critically about the material I am reading, and it is something I am going to take with me to every Yale class I take.
Learned about many of the underlying forces in our medical system and drug law enforcement systems.

I gained a fundamental understanding of the history of various drugs and associated social, economic, and political themes in 20th century America. I learned how to understand the various layers and aspects of the development, advertisement, politicization, racialization/criminalization, and more of different drugs.

I learned so much about the history of drugs and addiction and the structures that distinguish illegal/legla drug markets, who can take certain drugs and who are denied, physician privilege, pharmaceutical optimism, etc

I learned about how certain drugs evolved in use over time and how marketing methods developed along with changes in policy. A big focus of the course was on recognizing associations between certain groups of people and certain substances and understanding how that impacted public sentiment and government policy.
I learned to think critically about drug usage and sanctions in contemporary times, as well as the fascinating history behind different classes of drugs!

A new perspective on all kinds of drugs, including the medical and social components of each. This course really forces you (in a great way) to reevaluate your preconceived notions about how we have been socialized to fear (or judge, accept embrace) certain drugs and why this has been the case as it is so often not about the drug itself. It completely changed many of my views and has made me a more thoughtful person overall.

Racism in medicine/STEM environments; intersection between expansion of policing and criminalization of alcohol during Prohibition; histories of  psychedelics, cannabis, birth control, antidepressants, stimulants, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses. Prof. Ramos curated a beautiful syllabus that highlights BIPOC experiences (so rare) in such a respectful way. All of the readings are more than doable and so interesting that you don't realize you are doing homework.
This course was very engaging. The class was a very safe and open space for the exchange of ideas and questions. The reading list was perfectly curated for class discussion.
You learn things in a format that makes every thing interesting and humanizes it. you're not just learning information but also how it effects real people.

I have no weaknesses to share, this class was hands down one of the best classes I've taken at Yale! Strengths include: incredibly engaging class material, students, TF, prof, and readings; assignments were meaningful and organized to maximize our learning, excitement about our own topics, and feedback from both peers and the teaching team; incredibly caring and safe space for invaluable discussion.
The seminar is so open and non judgemental, was a fantastic space for learning

Strengths: Everything about the course! I loved how Professor Ramos provided a larger context in the beginning of our seminar and allowed us to use both our readings and additional knowledge to meaningfully contribute.  Everyone was actively engaged and opened to one another! Both Professor Ramos and Sydney were great at providing us with additional context and were very available to answer any of our questions. 
Weaknesses: Nothing
This was an amazing course. The only thing I would want more of is more scientific descriptions or readings about the medical side of things.

I really enjoyed the discussion seminar format and Professor Ramos and Sydney were definitely strengths of the course. I would say a potential weakness would be the readings - I know the reading load for a seminar class is usually high, but there were often times when I wished we could go deeper into the readings or times where we'd be assigned a reading that was barely covered in class.

Strengths: This is the best HSHM seminar I have taken and one of the best classes at Yale in my opinion. Prof. Ramos is an incredible instructor and created a super warm, engaging learning environment, facilitated as well by Sydney and the other students. The readings were fascinating and Prof. clearly spent lots of time designing the class, bringing in other forms of media like videos, art, and podcasts. I feel very lucky to have taken the class with such a dedicated professor despite him also being busy with his clinical work.
Weaknesses: None come to mind, perhaps there could have been more opportunities for drafting and getting feedback on the final paper. Another guest speaker (perhaps an addiction specialist or historian of drugs) could have been a super interesting addition but again, the class was great on its own. I would just encourage future students to really show up with an open mind and share your thoughts without fear of judgement, because Prof. Ramos just wants you to learn and grow.

Wonderful and genuinely caring professor and teaching assistant - very understanding of the difficulties during the pandemic
Very open and vulnerable class - great discussions
Unpacked readings together, everyone was really engaged
Walked us through writing processes, helped us develop skills
I love this course. Prof. Marcos is wonderful and the energy created in this class from students and teaching staff was one that I have not experienced in other courses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! This course will challenge your perceptions of drugs, drug users, and the medical society we live in. I have never been so intellectually stimulated.

Yes, if I were to take any course at Yale, it would be this one.  This class made me look forward to attending a Friday afternoon seminar. This class was very engaging and informative, and the readings were always interesting. I walked away from each class feeling like I had learned something new. If you are a premedical student or are in anyway interested in psychiatry, take this class. The final paper could be a bit challenging, but it is worth the work.
yes. all pre-meds should take this to understand how we the way we think about drugs effects all in our society
Absolutely take this course if you have the chance. Prof. Ramos is an incredible professor and the topics we covered are relevant to everyone.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!!! one of the best classes I've taken at Yale that brought together so many themes from other classes and contextualized them in incredibly important issues surrounding drugs and addiction. Prof Ramos is absolutely amazing and makes the class so welcoming and engaging.
Yes
Absolutley! One of my favorite courses at Yale I have taken.
Definitely! This class is a gem!
I would absolutely recommend this course, especially if you are interested in drug policy or medicine and want to see more perspectives.

I would highly recommend this course to another student - doing the readings and participating in class discussions really taught me to be more open-minded and critical about drug marketing and usage in current times.
Absolutely, 100%!

Yes! Really interesting and complex readings - helped me develop my writing skills, and I was able to write about what I was interested in. The professor and teaching assistant created such a welcoming and engaging environment.
yes! take any hsm course and you will learn so much. such an important area of study. prof. marcos and sydney greene were excellent!
